org.multiverse.utils.clock
Interface Clock

All Known Implementing Classes:
RelaxedClock, StrictClock
public interface Clock

A Clock: a logical timer. It is to make a sense of time possible so that concurrent transactions that commit are ordered. Unlike normal clocks that change based on linear time, a logical clock is non linear; sometimes there are bursts and some there is not much to do. Time is increased by calling tick()

Concurrent transactions are only interesting when there is shared state. Transactions that don't share state are not ordered. So the relation partially orders transactions in time. Only transactions that share state are fully ordered. It they weren't, the system would start to suffer from isolation problems:

  1. transactions seeing state of other transactions that completed before it did.
  2. a transaction not seeing state of other transactions that started after the transaction but completed before (in databases this is called the lost update problem).

Small Warning

The Clock is based on a long, so there is a limit on the total time a clock is able to live. If a clock lives longer, the time could go 'back' when the long flows over to the negative side. In most cases this won't cause problems; it the dawn time is zero and there are 1.000.0000.0000 transactions per second, only after Long.MAX_VALUE/1.000.0000.000 transactions per second, the clock is able to run for 9223372036 second; which is 292 years. And with a dawn starting at Long.MIN_VALUE it is 584 years. So atm this is not going to be a problem.

Author:
Peter Veentjer.

Method Summary
 long getDawn()
          Returns the time of dawn; the time this clock was created.
 long getTime()
          Returns the current time.
 long tick()
          Executes a clock tick (so increases the 'time').
 

Method Detail

tick

long tick()
Executes a clock tick (so increases the 'time'). The returned value could be stale as soon as it is received. The returned value will always be bigger than the current time. Once the tick method completes, the getTime() method will always return a time equal or larger than.the last tick.

Returns:
the time after the tick.

getTime

long getTime()
Returns the current time. The returned value could be stale as soon as it is received.

Returns:
the current time.

getDawn

long getDawn()
Returns the time of dawn; the time this clock was created.

Returns:
time of dawn.
